column1: Buena Park () is a city in northwestern Orange County
column2: about 12 miles (20 km) northwest of downtown Santa Ana
column3: the county seat. As of Census 2010 its population was 80
column4: 530. It is the location of several tourist attractions
column5: including Knott's Berry Farm. It is located about 24 miles southeast of Downtown Los Angeles and is within the Los Angeles metropolitan area.

column1: Original Spanish explorers settled on the enormous ranchos by land grants made by the King of Spain. Manuel Nieto of the Portolà expeditions received such a grant in 1783
column2: which was divided by his heirs into five separate ranchos in 1834. One of them
column5: included the current site of the City of Buena Park. The rancho's adobe headquarters lay on what is now Los Coyotes Country Club's golf course.

column1: The area was transferred from Spanish authority to Mexican rule in 1822 and ceded to the United States in 1848 at the end of the Mexican–American War. California was granted statehood in 1850. Americanization further expanded in the area after completion of the transcontinental railroad in 1869 and its connection to Los Angeles in 1875. By then
column2: Abel Stearns had acquired Rancho Los Coyotes in consideration for loans made to Pio and Andrés Pico. In 1885
column5: purchased 690 acres (2.8 km2) of this land from Stearns. In 1887
column6: Whitaker founded the City of Buena Park in conjunction with the railway development of what we now know as Orange County.

column1: The exact derivation of the name Buena Park is uncertain. One theory is that Whitaker used the name of a Chicago suburb: Buena Park
column2: Chicago
column4: although the community in Illinois was also named in 1887. Another theory relates to the artesian well and its park-like grounds once located at the current intersection of what are now Artesia and Beach Boulevards. Local settlers referred to the area as "Plaza Buena" which means "good park" in Spanish.

column1: The City of Buena Park has its own local history park on Beach Blvd just south of Interstate 5. On these grounds
column2: the city has preserved several historic buildings. These include the Whitaker-Jaynes House (which serves as the city's local history museum) the Bacon House - possibly the oldest surviving structure from the area
column3: the Stage Stop Hotel (which houses the California Welcome Center-Orange County) and the Tice House. The Buena Park Historical Society manages and maintains the historical content of the museum. The Dreger Clock
column5: best known for the time it spent at Knott's Berry Farm
column6: was installed in front of the Whitaker/Jaynes house overlooking Beach Blvd in September 2009 after a two-year restoration project.

column1: A Nabisco factory on Artesia Boulevard was known for many years as a Buena Park landmark. The red "Nabisco" sign was visible from the I-5 Freeway
column2: and visitors to the town could often smell cookies. The factory produced Honey Maid graham crackers
column5: among other Nabisco products

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 10.6 square miles (27 km2). 10.5 square miles (27 km2) of it is land and 0.03 square miles (0.078 km2) of it (0.28%) is water. One of the things Buena Park citizens are proud of is that Buena Park is considered the center of the southland.

column1: Supermarket chain 99 Ranch Market is based in Buena Park. A Nabisco factory built in 1965 once employed as many as 500 before being shut down; it was demolished in 2006.
Buena Park was incorporated as a General Law City on January 27
column2: 1953. In November 2008
column3: the voters adopted a City Charter. The City Charter is a written document approved by the electorate which acts as a “constitution” for the city. Amendments
column4: revisions and repeals of a charter are subject to the vote of the people.

column1: Buena Park operates under council–manager government
column2: in which the City Council is the policy-making body and the City Manager is responsible for carrying out Council policy and everyday management of city functions. An elected City Council of five non-partisan members is elected at large and its chair acts as mayor.Current city council members are Mayor Fred Smith

column1: The United States Postal Service Buena Park Post Office is at 7377 La Palma Avenue.
Buena Park is home to one of the 13 special district libraries in California. The Buena Park Library District is a single-purpose library district governed by an elected Board of Trustees
column2: and has as its principal source of income through property tax proration. The library's early history is much like other communities: it operated on and off as a volunteer operation beginning in 1905 at several temporary locations with donated books. It was formally established as a library district through the efforts of the Buena Park Woman's Club in 1919. The current facility's construction was completed in early 1969 financed by a bond measure passed by the citizens of Buena Park on June 6

column1: The city is served by seven different school districts. Buena Park School District covers nearly the entire northern half of the city

column5: Magnolia
column6: and Savanna serve the remainder of the city
column7: feeding into the Anaheim Union High School District. Buena Park High School is the only high school within city limits. Kennedy
column9: Sunny Hills and Western high schools also all serve the city's students

column1: Fire protection in Buena Park is provided by the Orange County Fire Authority. Law enforcement is provided by the Buena Park Police Department. Ambulance service is provided by Care Ambulance Service.
Buena Park's main commercial artery is Beach Boulevard
column2: (California State Route 39)
column3: running north–south and connecting the city's civic center
column5: and Buena Park Downtown shopping center.

column1: Three Caltrans state maintained highways run through the city. They include Interstate 5 (Santa Ana Freeway)
column2: California State Route 39 (Beach Boulevard) and California State Route 91 (Artesia Freeway). The freeways connect Buena Park with cities west–east and south–north respectively. The Orange County Transportation Authority provides public bus services
column3: but most residents rely on cars. Also
column4: one Los Angeles County Route runs through the city Los Angeles County Route N8 (La Mirada Boulevard)
column5: but only for a quarter of a mile. Other main arterials that run west–east include Ball Road
column11: Malvern Avenue and Alondra Boulevard; south–north main arterials include Valley View Street
column14: Beach Boulevard (SR 39) and Stanton Avenue. Cerritos Avenue runs along the south edge of the city
column15: Walker Street runs along the west edge of the city
column16: Rosecrans Avenue runs along the north edge of the city and Magnolia Avenue runs along the east edge of the city.

column1: Fullerton Municipal Airport is the closest airport
column2: but the nearest airport with commercial service is Long Beach Airport
column3: about 13 miles (21 km) to the southwest. Both Union Pacific (originally Southern Pacific) and BNSF railroad tracks cross the city. A Metrolink station in Buena Park opened in September 2007.
